title: What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface in Java?

answers.junior: Abstract classes and interfaces are both mechanisms for achieving abstraction in Java, but they serve different purposes and have distinct characteristics. An abstract class can contain both abstract methods (without implementation) and concrete methods (with implementation), instance variables with any access modifier, constructors, and can maintain state, while an interface (prior to Java 8) could only declare abstract methods and constants (public static final fields).
answers.middle: Abstract classes and interfaces are both mechanisms for achieving abstraction in Java, but they serve different purposes and have distinct characteristics. An abstract class can contain both abstract methods (without implementation) and concrete methods (with implementation), instance variables with any access modifier, constructors, and can maintain state, while an interface (prior to Java 8) could only declare abstract methods and constants (public static final fields). From Java 8 onwards, interfaces gained default methods and static methods, blurring some distinctions: `interface Flyable { default void fly() { System.out.println("Flying"); } }`. A class can extend only one abstract class (single inheritance) but can implement multiple interfaces, making interfaces the primary tool for achieving multiple inheritance of type.
answers.senior: Abstract classes and interfaces are both mechanisms for achieving abstraction in Java, but they serve different purposes and have distinct characteristics. An abstract class can contain both abstract methods (without implementation) and concrete methods (with implementation), instance variables with any access modifier, constructors, and can maintain state, while an interface (prior to Java 8) could only declare abstract methods and constants (public static final fields). From Java 8 onwards, interfaces gained default methods and static methods, blurring some distinctions: `interface Flyable { default void fly() { System.out.println("Flying"); } }`. A class can extend only one abstract class (single inheritance) but can implement multiple interfaces, making interfaces the primary tool for achieving multiple inheritance of type. Abstract classes use `abstract class Animal { abstract void makeSound(); }` and are extended with `class Dog extends Animal { void makeSound() { System.out.println("Bark"); } }`, while interfaces use `interface Runnable { void run(); }` and are implemented with `class Task implements Runnable { public void run() { } }`. Abstract classes are ideal when you have a clear 'is-a' relationship with shared implementation and state among subclasses (e.g., Animal hierarchy), while interfaces define contracts and capabilities that unrelated classes can implement (e.g., Serializable, Comparable). Abstract class methods can have any access modifier (public, protected, private), but interface methods are implicitly public (except private methods in Java 9+). Java 9 introduced private methods in interfaces for code reuse within default methods, and Java 8 added static methods for utility functions.
